title: China Eximbank provides RMB 249 million government concessional loan for National Broadband Expansion Project (Linked to Project ID#56033)
description: On September 22, 2018, the Chinese Government and the Government of Guyana signed a preferential loan framework agreement for the National Broadband Expansion Project. Then, on October 26, 2018, China Eximbank and the Government of Guyana signed an RMB 249,043,600 ($37.6 million) government concessional loan (GCL) agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO. (2018) 26 TOTAL NO. (668)] for the National Broadband Expansion Project. The GCL carries the following borrowing terms: a 2% interest rate, a 0% default (penalty) interest rate, a 5-year grace period, a 20-year maturity period, a 0.25% commitment fee, and a 0.25% (RMB 622,609) management fee. The proceeds of the GCL are to be used by the borrower to finance a $37.6 million commercial (EPC) contract (ID# OY03281700000E) between the Ministry of Communications of Guyana and Huawei Technologies Co. Ltd, which was signed on November 6, 2017. As of December 31, 2020, the loan had achieved a 95.7% disbursement rate ($35,991,584 out of $37,600,000) and its total amount outstanding (including principal and capitalized interest) was RMB 243,549,000.   The purpose of the project is to expand and upgrade the country’s existing e-government network in order to improve the efficacy of government services in four areas: (1) smart government solutions, (2) safe city solutions, (3) smart education, and (4) smart healthcare. The project also involves components that involved the construction of Long-term Evolution (LTE) towers, the equipping of a data center, the equipping of a unified emergency call center, the construction of a command center for the police keep track of patrol cars, an expansion of Closed Circuit Television (CCTV) monitoring, and training and human resource capacity building activities. The stated purpose of the “safe city" component of the project is to enable the Guyana Police Force to track license plates and other documents, improve response times, and access critical information in real time. Huawei Technologies Co. Ltd and Guyana’s National Data Management Authority are responsible for project implementation. The project commenced in November 2019. As of late 2019, the Safe City component of the project was ‘largely complete’. By December 31, 2020, the China Eximbank loan had achieved an 95.7% disbursement rate ($35,991,584.40 out of $37,600,000).   This project has provoked local scrutiny and controversy due to the use of facial recognition technology in the smart city component and the possibility that Huawei would gain access to the Government of Guyana’s data systems. In November 2020, the Prime Minister of Guyana said that security concerns by the public had been heard and that measures would be put in place to guard against breaches, but he did not explain how this would be accomplished.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Guyana National Broadband Project and the NBEP Project.  2. The China Eximbank loan agreement can be accessed in its entirety via https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/20488287-guy_2017_461 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/kwxk7hpv0dyicpi/DRS%20Official%20Commitments%20from%20China%20through%202020.csv?dl=0. 3. Huawei also implemented the China Eximbank-financed E-Government Network Project in Guyana (as captured via Project ID#56033). 4. A detailed overview of the National Broadband Expansion Project’s achievements (vis-a-vis the original contractual deliverables and deadlines) as of November 2020 can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/ae435vtbajk6pzc/MF-Phillips-on-Broadband2-2-scaled.jpeg?dl=0. 5. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not captured in the China-Latin America Finance Database maintained by Boston University and Inter-American Dialogue. Nor is it included in China’s Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University's Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 249 million government concessional loan for National Broadband Expansion Project (Linked to Project ID#56033)

# Description
On September 22, 2018, the Chinese Government and the Government of Guyana signed a preferential loan framework agreement for the National Broadband Expansion Project. Then, on October 26, 2018, China Eximbank and the Government of Guyana signed an RMB 249,043,600 ($37.6 million) government concessional loan (GCL) agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO. (2018) 26 TOTAL NO. (668)] for the National Broadband Expansion Project. The GCL carries the following borrowing terms: a 2% interest rate, a 0% default (penalty) interest rate, a 5-year grace period, a 20-year maturity period, a 0.25% commitment fee, and a 0.25% (RMB 622,609) management fee. The proceeds of the GCL are to be used by the borrower to finance a $37.6 million commercial (EPC) contract (ID# OY03281700000E) between the Ministry of Communications of Guyana and Huawei Technologies Co. Ltd, which was signed on November 6, 2017. As of December 31, 2020, the loan had achieved a 95.7% disbursement rate ($35,991,584 out of $37,600,000) and its total amount outstanding (including principal and capitalized interest) was RMB 243,549,000.   The purpose of the project is to expand and upgrade the country’s existing e-government network in order to improve the efficacy of government services in four areas: (1) smart government solutions, (2) safe city solutions, (3) smart education, and (4) smart healthcare. The project also involves components that involved the construction of Long-term Evolution (LTE) towers, the equipping of a data center, the equipping of a unified emergency call center, the construction of a command center for the police keep track of patrol cars, an expansion of Closed Circuit Television (CCTV) monitoring, and training and human resource capacity building activities. The stated purpose of the “safe city" component of the project is to enable the Guyana Police Force to track license plates and other documents, improve response times, and access critical information in real time. Huawei Technologies Co. Ltd and Guyana’s National Data Management Authority are responsible for project implementation. The project commenced in November 2019. As of late 2019, the Safe City component of the project was ‘largely complete’. By December 31, 2020, the China Eximbank loan had achieved an 95.7% disbursement rate ($35,991,584.40 out of $37,600,000).   This project has provoked local scrutiny and controversy due to the use of facial recognition technology in the smart city component and the possibility that Huawei would gain access to the Government of Guyana’s data systems. In November 2020, the Prime Minister of Guyana said that security concerns by the public had been heard and that measures would be put in place to guard against breaches, but he did not explain how this would be accomplished.
justification: Project focuses on communications infrastructure and e-government services without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Broadband expansion, e-government network, LTE towers, data center, emergency call center, CCTV monitoring, training activities

title: Chinese Government provides $10 million grant — via ETCA — for Bertram Collins College Headquarters Construction Project
description: On September 22, 2018, the Chinese Government and the Government of Guyana signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), which committed RMB 100 million ($14 million) of grant funding for multiple projects. China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) reportedly allocated $10 million of grant funding from the ETCA for the Bertram Collins College Headquarters Construction Project.   The purpose of the project is to construct a modern, state-of-the-art facility — with a lecture room, canteen, gym, and study areas — on a 29-acre parcel of land in Ogle, East Coast Demerara — where the Guyana Sugar Corporation (GuySuCo) was once headquartered. As of August 26, 2020, the Chinese Government had already dispatched engineers, surveyors and other experts to the project site to conduct soil-testing and evaluate the viability of the project site. However, construction had not yet commenced. Then, in February 2021, the Irfaan Ali administration decided to close the Bertram Collins College of the Public Service. Vice President, Dr. Bharrat Jagdeo, said during a press conference that the David Granger Coalition Government had been using the College to run its political campaign with taxpayer dollars. The Vice President was responding to concerns that the decision to close the school was motivated by ethno-political bias. He noted that the People’s Progressive Party Civic (PPP/C) had held long ago that it would dismantle the school: ‘We campaigned on that. It’s not a secret,’ Dr. Jagdeo said. ‘As Leader of the Opposition, I said that. I said we’d save the money… and put it into other things that are more useful for people. We didn’t hide that before.’
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Bertram Collins College of the Public Service Construction Project and the Public Service College Project. 2. The Bertram Collins College of the Public Service is the brain-child of President David Granger following years of criticism of the public service for poor customer service. The college does not only provide training for current public servants, but also caters to school-leavers who are interested in pursuing a career there.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides $10 million grant — via ETCA — for Bertram Collins College Headquarters Construction Project

# Description
On September 22, 2018, the Chinese Government and the Government of Guyana signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), which committed RMB 100 million ($14 million) of grant funding for multiple projects. China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) reportedly allocated $10 million of grant funding from the ETCA for the Bertram Collins College Headquarters Construction Project.   The purpose of the project is to construct a modern, state-of-the-art facility — with a lecture room, canteen, gym, and study areas — on a 29-acre parcel of land in Ogle, East Coast Demerara — where the Guyana Sugar Corporation (GuySuCo) was once headquartered. As of August 26, 2020, the Chinese Government had already dispatched engineers, surveyors and other experts to the project site to conduct soil-testing and evaluate the viability of the project site. However, construction had not yet commenced. Then, in February 2021, the Irfaan Ali administration decided to close the Bertram Collins College of the Public Service. Vice President, Dr. Bharrat Jagdeo, said during a press conference that the David Granger Coalition Government had been using the College to run its political campaign with taxpayer dollars. The Vice President was responding to concerns that the decision to close the school was motivated by ethno-political bias. He noted that the People’s Progressive Party Civic (PPP/C) had held long ago that it would dismantle the school: ‘We campaigned on that. It’s not a secret,’ Dr. Jagdeo said. ‘As Leader of the Opposition, I said that. I said we’d save the money… and put it into other things that are more useful for people. We didn’t hide that before.’
justification: Project focuses on education infrastructure with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Construction of college headquarters with educational facilities, no energy-related components mentioned

title: Chinese Embassy of Guyana donates computers to Guyana's Ministry of Agriculture
description: On June 1, 2018, the Chinese Embassy of Guyana donates a batch of computers to Guyana's Department of Agriculture. The computers will be distributed to regional Fishing Administration Offices to compensate for the lack of office equipment. Chen Xilai, Political Counselor of the Embassy, ​​and Naid, Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Agriculture of Guyana, attended the donation ceremony. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Embassy of Guyana donates computers to Guyana's Ministry of Agriculture

# Description
On June 1, 2018, the Chinese Embassy of Guyana donates a batch of computers to Guyana's Department of Agriculture. The computers will be distributed to regional Fishing Administration Offices to compensate for the lack of office equipment. Chen Xilai, Political Counselor of the Embassy, ​​and Naid, Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Agriculture of Guyana, attended the donation ceremony. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
justification: Donation of computers to government offices for administrative purposes, no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Computer donation to Ministry of Agriculture, intended for administrative use in Fishing Administration Offices

title: Chinese Embassy of Guyana donates a batch of books to the National Library of Guyana
description: On May 30, 2018, the Chinese Embassy of Guyana donates a batch of English books to the National Library of Guyana. The books cover topics including Chinese politics, economy, culture, etc. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Embassy of Guyana donates a batch of books to the National Library of Guyana

# Description
On May 30, 2018, the Chinese Embassy of Guyana donates a batch of English books to the National Library of Guyana. The books cover topics including Chinese politics, economy, culture, etc. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.
justification: Project is a cultural donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Book donation to National Library, focus on cultural exchange

title: Chinese Government finances the 2018 Overseas Training Course on Aquaculture Technology for Guyana
description: In 2018, China's Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM), in partnership with the Fisheries Department of Guyana's Ministry of Agriculture and Fujian Institute of Oceanography (FJIO), financed the 2018 Overseas Training Course on Aquaculture Technology for Guyana ​. The training was intended to improve the technological and managerial capabilities of Guyanese aquaculture so as to promote the development of the industry. The training covered topics including the construction of breed ponds, water quality and disease prevention and control. The training was implemented by FJIO. FJIO sent an assessment team in April 2018 for a pre-stage field investigation for the implementation of the program.   The program's 57 trainees were drawn from Regions One, Two, Three, Four, Five, Six, and Nine and included the Fisheries Department of Guyana's Ministry of Agriculture, fish farmers, teachers, students from the University of Guyana (the Turkeyen and Tain campuses) and the Guyana School of Agriculture, and Guyana Defence Force (GDF) officers. The training was held at the Regency Suite Hotel in Georgetown. The training included sessions at the Satyadeow Sawh Aquaculture Station and a field trip to a shrimp farm in Region Six. The 10-day long training began on November 28, 2018. The training was scheduled on December 11, 2018. However, the course ended on December 10, 2018, following visits by the participants to the Sweet Water Aqua Farm at Canal #2, West Bank Demerara and the Satyadeow Sawh Aquaculture Station at Mon Repos.  MOFCOM had previously financed the 2017 Overseas Training Course on Aquaculture Technology for Guyana in September 2017, as captured by linked project ID#.
staff_comments: The Chinese course title is 2018年圭亚那水产养殖技术海外培训班.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Chinese Government finances the 2018 Overseas Training Course on Aquaculture Technology for Guyana

# Description
In 2018, China's Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM), in partnership with the Fisheries Department of Guyana's Ministry of Agriculture and Fujian Institute of Oceanography (FJIO), financed the 2018 Overseas Training Course on Aquaculture Technology for Guyana ​. The training was intended to improve the technological and managerial capabilities of Guyanese aquaculture so as to promote the development of the industry. The training covered topics including the construction of breed ponds, water quality and disease prevention and control. The training was implemented by FJIO. FJIO sent an assessment team in April 2018 for a pre-stage field investigation for the implementation of the program.   The program's 57 trainees were drawn from Regions One, Two, Three, Four, Five, Six, and Nine and included the Fisheries Department of Guyana's Ministry of Agriculture, fish farmers, teachers, students from the University of Guyana (the Turkeyen and Tain campuses) and the Guyana School of Agriculture, and Guyana Defence Force (GDF) officers. The training was held at the Regency Suite Hotel in Georgetown. The training included sessions at the Satyadeow Sawh Aquaculture Station and a field trip to a shrimp farm in Region Six. The 10-day long training began on November 28, 2018. The training was scheduled on December 11, 2018. However, the course ended on December 10, 2018, following visits by the participants to the Sweet Water Aqua Farm at Canal #2, West Bank Demerara and the Satyadeow Sawh Aquaculture Station at Mon Repos.  MOFCOM had previously financed the 2017 Overseas Training Course on Aquaculture Technology for Guyana in September 2017, as captured by linked project ID#.
justification: Project is focused on capacity building and training in aquaculture technology, with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Training course on aquaculture technology, capacity building focus, no energy-related components

title: Chinese Government donates medical equipment and supplies worth RMB 1.1 million to Georgetown Public Hospital Corporation
description: On December 28, 2018, in the presence of members of the fourteenth Chinese medical team to Guyana (see project ID#71210), the Chinese Government donated medical equipment and supplies worth RMB 1.1 million ($28 million GYD) to Georgetown Public Hospital Corporation. The donation, which included medical equipment, anesthetic drugs, and other supplies, was intended to bolster the hospital's general surgery, plastic surgery, and orthopedics departments.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates medical equipment and supplies worth RMB 1.1 million to Georgetown Public Hospital Corporation

# Description
On December 28, 2018, in the presence of members of the fourteenth Chinese medical team to Guyana (see project ID#71210), the Chinese Government donated medical equipment and supplies worth RMB 1.1 million ($28 million GYD) to Georgetown Public Hospital Corporation. The donation, which included medical equipment, anesthetic drugs, and other supplies, was intended to bolster the hospital's general surgery, plastic surgery, and orthopedics departments.
justification: Project is a healthcare donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical equipment and supplies donation to hospital, no energy-related components

title: Chinese Government sends 14th medical team to Guyana
description: In June 2018, China dispatched the fourteenth medical team to Georgetown Hospital and Linden Hospital in Guyana. The team is administered by the Jiangsu Provincial Government. The fourteenth medical team consisted of 16 people, covering general surgery, ophthalmology, acupuncture and massage, radiology, nephrology, plastic surgery, histopathology, obstetrics and gynecology, orthopedics, anesthesiology, pediatrics and other fields. The experts piloted three new surgical techniques for the Georgetown Hospital and attended to 16,440 outpatients. The team also donated medical supplies to the country. The project was completed and the team returned in June 2019. The Guyana Ministry of Public Health hosted an appreciation dinner for the team.  The thirteenth batch was sent to Guyana in 2017 (see Project ID #71208), the twelfth batch of doctors was sent to Guyana in 2016 (see Project ID #71207), the eleventh batch of doctors to Guyana was sent in 2014 (see Project ID #71206), and the tenth batch in 2012 (see Project ID #71205). A sixth batch is recorded by Project ID #71201. Since 1993, China has sent over 160 medical experts to assist Guyana.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government sends 14th medical team to Guyana

# Description
In June 2018, China dispatched the fourteenth medical team to Georgetown Hospital and Linden Hospital in Guyana. The team is administered by the Jiangsu Provincial Government. The fourteenth medical team consisted of 16 people, covering general surgery, ophthalmology, acupuncture and massage, radiology, nephrology, plastic surgery, histopathology, obstetrics and gynecology, orthopedics, anesthesiology, pediatrics and other fields. The experts piloted three new surgical techniques for the Georgetown Hospital and attended to 16,440 outpatients. The team also donated medical supplies to the country. The project was completed and the team returned in June 2019. The Guyana Ministry of Public Health hosted an appreciation dinner for the team.  The thirteenth batch was sent to Guyana in 2017 (see Project ID #71208), the twelfth batch of doctors was sent to Guyana in 2016 (see Project ID #71207), the eleventh batch of doctors to Guyana was sent in 2014 (see Project ID #71206), and the tenth batch in 2012 (see Project ID #71205). A sixth batch is recorded by Project ID #71201. Since 1993, China has sent over 160 medical experts to assist Guyana.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare provision and medical expertise transfer, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical team deployment, healthcare services provided, medical supplies donated

title: Chinese Government donates medical supplies and equipment worth $6.2 million GYD to Linden Hospital Complex
description: On December 19, 2018, in the presence of members of the fourteenth Chinese medical team to Guyana (see project ID#71210), the Chinese Government donated medical supplies and equipment worth $6.2 million GYD to Linden Hospital Complex (LHC). The donated items included ultrasonic atomization, atomizer energy chips, syringe pumps, oxygen pumps, and infant oxygen hoods. The items would be distributed to LHC and the Kwakwani Hospital and, if necessary, the Upper Demerara Hospital.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates medical supplies and equipment worth $6.2 million GYD to Linden Hospital Complex

# Description
On December 19, 2018, in the presence of members of the fourteenth Chinese medical team to Guyana (see project ID#71210), the Chinese Government donated medical supplies and equipment worth $6.2 million GYD to Linden Hospital Complex (LHC). The donated items included ultrasonic atomization, atomizer energy chips, syringe pumps, oxygen pumps, and infant oxygen hoods. The items would be distributed to LHC and the Kwakwani Hospital and, if necessary, the Upper Demerara Hospital.
justification: Project involves donation of medical equipment to healthcare facilities with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical supplies and equipment donation to hospitals, healthcare sector focus

title: Chinese Embassy signed a MoU of a 4.6 million GYD grant to fund a new language lab at the University of Guyana
description: On June 5, 2018, the Chinese Embassy in Guyana and the University of Guyana sign a memorandum of understanding in which the Chinese Embassy would provide a 4.6 million GYD grant to fund the acquisition of furniture, computers, headsets and other items for the creation of a new language lab. The facility is expected to be functional in September 2018, for the 2018-2019 academic year.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Embassy signed a MoU of a 4.6 million GYD grant to fund a new language lab at the University of Guyana

# Description
On June 5, 2018, the Chinese Embassy in Guyana and the University of Guyana sign a memorandum of understanding in which the Chinese Embassy would provide a 4.6 million GYD grant to fund the acquisition of furniture, computers, headsets and other items for the creation of a new language lab. The facility is expected to be functional in September 2018, for the 2018-2019 academic year.
justification: Project focuses on educational infrastructure development without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Funding for language lab equipment and furniture at university, educational purpose

title: Chinese Government provides $1.1 million USD grant to support Guyana's hosting of the CRIC 17
description: On September 22, 2018, the Chinese embassy handed over the cash donation of $1.1 million USD for Guyana's hosting of the Seventeenth Session of the Committee for the Review of the Implementation of the Convention (CRIC 17) in Georgetown. The donation allows Guyana to procure critical equipment for the convention centre to host the conference.   The Conference was held on January 28 to 30, 2019 at the Arthur Chung Convention Centre (ACCC) and saw the participation 94 countries, seven Inter-Government Organisations (IGOs), seven United Nations agencies and 20 Non-Governmental Organisations (NGOs).
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government provides $1.1 million USD grant to support Guyana's hosting of the CRIC 17

# Description
On September 22, 2018, the Chinese embassy handed over the cash donation of $1.1 million USD for Guyana's hosting of the Seventeenth Session of the Committee for the Review of the Implementation of the Convention (CRIC 17) in Georgetown. The donation allows Guyana to procure critical equipment for the convention centre to host the conference.   The Conference was held on January 28 to 30, 2019 at the Arthur Chung Convention Centre (ACCC) and saw the participation 94 countries, seven Inter-Government Organisations (IGOs), seven United Nations agencies and 20 Non-Governmental Organisations (NGOs).
justification: Project is a financial grant supporting a government conference, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: $1.1 million USD grant for hosting CRIC 17 conference, procurement of conference equipment
